source: FDA IVD Guidance + CLSI Standards + CAP/CLIA Requirements

analytical_performance.name: Analytical Sensitivity (Limit of Detection, LoD)
analytical_performance.definition: Lowest analyte concentration that can be reliably detected (e.g., 95% hit rate) above blank/negative control
analytical_performance.measurement_method: Serial dilution testing near expected limit; CLSI EP17-A2 protocol; probit or logit regression analysis
analytical_performance.success_criteria: LoD ≤claimed cutoff in IFU; consistent across 3+ lots and instruments
analytical_performance.clinical_significance: Determines minimum reportable value; critical for infectious disease tests (HIV viral load, HCV RNA)
analytical_performance.typical_analysis: Probit analysis with 95% hit rate; 95% CI for LoD; verification with ≥20 replicates at LoD
analytical_performance.regulatory_notes: FDA requires LoD verification in premarket study; must be validated for each specimen type (serum, plasma, whole blood)

analytical_performance.name: Analytical Specificity (Cross-Reactivity and Interference)
analytical_performance.definition: Cross-reactivity: Reactivity with non-target analytes. Interference: Effect of endogenous (hemolysis, lipemia, icterus) or exogenous substances on results
analytical_performance.measurement_method: Test structurally similar compounds at physiologic concentrations; test hemolyzed, lipemic, icteric samples per CLSI EP7
analytical_performance.success_criteria: No cross-reactivity with structurally similar analytes at 10× expected concentration; No interference at clinically relevant hemolysis/lipemia/icterus levels
analytical_performance.source: CLSI EP7-A3 (Interference Testing), FDA IVD Guidance
analytical_performance.clinical_significance: Prevents false positives (cross-reactivity) and false results (interference); critical for point-of-care and emergency tests
analytical_performance.typical_analysis: Percent bias from expected value; acceptance if bias <±10% or within total allowable error
analytical_performance.regulatory_notes: Test ≥20 potentially cross-reactive substances for immunoassays; test hemolysis (500 mg/dL Hb), lipemia (2000 mg/dL triglycerides), icterus (20 mg/dL bilirubin)

analytical_performance.name: Precision (Repeatability and Reproducibility)
analytical_performance.definition: Repeatability: Within-run precision (same operator, reagent lot, instrument, run). Reproducibility: Between-run, between-day, between-lot, between-site precision
analytical_performance.measurement_method: CLSI EP05-A3 protocol: 2+ levels, 2 replicates/run, 2 runs/day, 20 days; calculate within-run, between-run, between-day, total CV
analytical_performance.success_criteria: CV ≤claimed precision in IFU; CV ≤50% of total allowable error (TEa)
analytical_performance.clinical_significance: Low precision leads to false changes in serial monitoring (e.g., HbA1c, troponin); precision component of total error budget
analytical_performance.typical_analysis: ANOVA to partition variance components; report CV% for within-run, between-run, total; calculate repeatability and reproducibility SD
analytical_performance.regulatory_notes: Test at 3 levels (low, mid, high across reportable range); minimum 20 days for reproducibility; multi-site study (3 sites) for PMA devices

analytical_performance.name: Linearity and Reportable Range
analytical_performance.definition: Linearity: Proportional response across concentration range. Reportable Range: Span of results that meet accuracy, precision, and bias requirements
analytical_performance.measurement_method: CLSI EP06 protocol: Dilute high sample and mix with low sample to create 9-11 levels; linear regression; calculate %deviation from linearity
analytical_performance.success_criteria: R² ≥0.95 across claimed range; polynomial regression not superior to linear; %deviation ≤±10% across range
analytical_performance.clinical_significance: Ensures accurate results across physiologic and pathologic concentrations; determines need for dilution at high values
analytical_performance.typical_analysis: Linear regression with 95% CI for slope/intercept; polynomial fit comparison; plot residuals; calculate allowable nonlinearity
analytical_performance.regulatory_notes: If nonlinear, use polynomial regression or spline; verify at limits of reportable range; document dilution protocol if specimens exceed upper limit

analytical_performance.name: Accuracy (Method Comparison)
analytical_performance.definition: Agreement with comparative method (predicate device or reference standard) or recovery of spiked/certified reference material
analytical_performance.measurement_method: CLSI EP09-A3: Test ≥40 patient samples spanning range on new and comparative method; Deming or Passing-Bablok regression
analytical_performance.success_criteria: Slope 0.9-1.1, intercept near 0; bias ≤allowable bias from CLIA PT criteria or Ricos biologic variation database
analytical_performance.source: CLSI EP09-A3 (Method Comparison), CLSI EP15-A3 (User Verification)
analytical_performance.clinical_significance: Ensures new test produces clinically equivalent results to established test; critical for treatment thresholds (glucose, INR)
analytical_performance.typical_analysis: Deming regression (accounts for error in both methods); Bland-Altman plot for bias assessment; calculate mean bias and 95% limits of agreement
analytical_performance.regulatory_notes: Comparative method must be FDA-cleared or clinical reference standard; if no comparator, use certified reference materials (NIST, CAP); document traceability chain

analytical_performance.name: Analytical Measuring Interval (AMI)
analytical_performance.definition: Concentration range over which device measures analyte directly without dilution or concentration
analytical_performance.measurement_method: Combine linearity (EP06) and precision (EP05) data; AMI = range where CV ≤specified limit AND linearity met
analytical_performance.success_criteria: AMI encompasses 95% of expected patient values; extension beyond AMI requires validated dilution protocol
analytical_performance.source: CLSI C28-A3 (Defining, Establishing, and Verifying Reference Intervals)
analytical_performance.clinical_significance: Defines range of direct measurement; values outside AMI require dilution (high) or concentration (low)
analytical_performance.typical_analysis: Verify LoD (lower limit), verify linearity and precision at upper limit; document dilution verification if applicable
analytical_performance.regulatory_notes: AMI different from reportable range (reportable range may include diluted specimens)

analytical_performance.name: Stability (Specimen, On-Board, Reagent)
analytical_performance.definition: Specimen stability: Time/temperature limits for specimens before testing. On-board: Loaded specimen stability on analyzer. Reagent: Unopened and opened reagent expiration
analytical_performance.measurement_method: Test specimens at T0, then after storage at claimed conditions (e.g., 2-8°C for 24h, RT for 4h); bias ≤±10% or TEa
analytical_performance.success_criteria: Claimed stability supported by data; bias ≤±10% at stability limit timepoint vs. fresh specimen
analytical_performance.source: CLSI H18-A4 (Blood collection), device-specific FDA guidance
analytical_performance.clinical_significance: Defines specimen handling requirements; unstable analytes (ammonia, lactic acid) require immediate testing or stabilizers
analytical_performance.typical_analysis: Paired t-test or Wilcoxon for fresh vs. stored; calculate %bias; test at 3 levels (low, mid, high)
analytical_performance.regulatory_notes: Test worst-case storage (highest temp, longest time); include freeze-thaw cycles if applicable; on-board stability critical for random-access analyzers

clinical_performance.name: Clinical Sensitivity (True Positive Rate, Recall)
clinical_performance.definition: Proportion of specimens from patients with disease/condition that test positive
clinical_performance.measurement_method: Test prospective or retrospective specimens from diseased patients (defined by reference standard); calculate TP/(TP+FN)
clinical_performance.success_criteria: Sensitivity ≥claimed in IFU; typically ≥95% for screening tests (HIV, HCV), ≥80% for diagnostic tests
clinical_performance.source: CLSI EP12-A2 (User Protocol for Evaluation of Qualitative Test Performance)
clinical_performance.clinical_significance: High sensitivity needed for screening tests (rule out disease); low sensitivity leads to false negatives and missed diagnoses
clinical_performance.typical_analysis: Calculate sensitivity with exact 95% CI (Clopper-Pearson); stratify by disease severity, time since onset, demographics
clinical_performance.regulatory_notes: Reference standard must be validated (culture, PCR, adjudication by expert panel); minimum 100-200 positive specimens for pivotal study; include early/late disease stages

clinical_performance.name: Clinical Specificity (True Negative Rate)
clinical_performance.definition: Proportion of specimens from patients without disease/condition that test negative
clinical_performance.measurement_method: Test specimens from healthy individuals or patients with other conditions; calculate TN/(TN+FP)
clinical_performance.success_criteria: Specificity ≥claimed in IFU; typically ≥95-99% for most diagnostic tests
clinical_performance.clinical_significance: High specificity needed for confirmatory tests (rule in disease); low specificity leads to false positives, unnecessary treatments, patient anxiety
clinical_performance.typical_analysis: Calculate specificity with exact 95% CI; stratify by cross-reactive conditions, demographics
clinical_performance.regulatory_notes: Include healthy controls AND patients with related conditions (e.g., flu test should test patients with other respiratory viruses); minimum 100-300 negative specimens

clinical_performance.name: Positive Predictive Value (PPV)
clinical_performance.definition: Proportion of positive test results that are true positives; depends on disease prevalence
clinical_performance.measurement_method: Calculate from sensitivity, specificity, and disease prevalence: PPV = (Sens × Prev) / [(Sens × Prev) + ((1-Spec) × (1-Prev))]
clinical_performance.success_criteria: PPV ≥50% for screening tests at population prevalence; report for multiple prevalence scenarios
clinical_performance.source: Bayesian probability; report in IFU per FDA IVD guidance
clinical_performance.clinical_significance: Clinically meaningful metric for positive results; low PPV means many false positives, requiring confirmatory testing
clinical_performance.typical_analysis: Calculate PPV for low (screening), moderate, and high (symptomatic) prevalence scenarios; sensitivity analysis
clinical_performance.regulatory_notes: FDA requires PPV/NPV reporting for home-use and OTC tests; use population prevalence estimates from CDC, literature

clinical_performance.name: Negative Predictive Value (NPV)
clinical_performance.definition: Proportion of negative test results that are true negatives
clinical_performance.measurement_method: Calculate from sensitivity, specificity, and prevalence: NPV = (Spec × (1-Prev)) / [(Spec × (1-Prev)) + ((1-Sens) × Prev)]
clinical_performance.success_criteria: NPV ≥95% for tests used to rule out disease
clinical_performance.clinical_significance: Critical for ruling out disease; low NPV means negative results not reassuring
clinical_performance.typical_analysis: Calculate for multiple prevalence scenarios; highest in low-prevalence populations
clinical_performance.regulatory_notes: Report in IFU with prevalence assumptions clearly stated

clinical_performance.name: Area Under ROC Curve (AUC)
clinical_performance.definition: Summary measure of diagnostic accuracy across all cutoff thresholds; ranges 0.5 (no discrimination) to 1.0 (perfect)
clinical_performance.measurement_method: For quantitative tests, plot sensitivity vs. (1-specificity) across range of cutoffs; calculate area under curve (trapezoid rule or nonparametric)
clinical_performance.success_criteria: AUC ≥0.80 (fair), ≥0.90 (excellent); compare to predicate device or clinical standard
clinical_performance.source: Hanley JA, McNeil BJ. Radiology 1982;143:29-36; FDA IVD statistical guidance
clinical_performance.clinical_significance: AUC represents probability that test ranks random disease patient higher than random healthy patient; useful for cutoff optimization
clinical_performance.typical_analysis: Nonparametric AUC with DeLong 95% CI; compare AUCs between devices or markers using DeLong test; plot ROC curve with optimal cutoff
clinical_performance.regulatory_notes: Include ROC analysis for novel biomarkers or when optimizing cutoff; document justification for chosen cutoff (Youden index, cost-benefit)

clinical_performance.name: Agreement (Qualitative Tests)
clinical_performance.definition: Overall percent agreement (positive and negative) between new and comparative method
clinical_performance.measurement_method: Test same specimens on both devices; construct 2×2 table; calculate PPA, NPA, OPA with 95% CI
clinical_performance.success_criteria: PPA and NPA ≥95%; overall agreement ≥95%; lower limit of 95% CI >90%
clinical_performance.source: CLSI EP12-A2; FDA Statistical Guidance on Reporting Results from Studies Evaluating Diagnostic Tests
clinical_performance.clinical_significance: For qualitative tests without gold standard, agreement to predicate demonstrates equivalence
clinical_performance.typical_analysis: 2×2 table with PPA = TP/(TP+FN), NPA = TN/(TN+FP), OPA = (TP+TN)/Total; exact 95% CI; kappa statistic for chance-corrected agreement
clinical_performance.regulatory_notes: PPA/NPA preferred over sensitivity/specificity when comparative method is not gold standard; minimum 100+ positive and 100+ negative by comparator

clinical_performance.name: Accuracy (Quantitative Tests with Reference Material)
clinical_performance.definition: Bias between measured value and certified reference material true value
clinical_performance.measurement_method: Test certified reference materials (NIST SRMs, CAP/AACC standards) at 3+ levels; calculate %bias = [(Measured - True)/True] × 100
clinical_performance.success_criteria: Bias ≤±10% or within CLIA PT limits across range
clinical_performance.source: ISO 17511 (Traceability of values assigned to calibrators and controls), CLSI C62-A
clinical_performance.clinical_significance: Ensures traceability to higher-order reference systems; critical for tests with treatment thresholds (glucose, cholesterol, INR)
clinical_performance.typical_analysis: Mean %bias with 95% CI at each level; compare to CLIA PT acceptance limits or biologic variation TEa
clinical_performance.regulatory_notes: Document full traceability chain: device → calibrator → reference material → primary reference (SI units if available); use JCTLM-listed reference materials

usability_and_real_world.name: Untrained User Study (Home/OTC Devices)
usability_and_real_world.definition: Evaluation of device use by intended users (patients, caregivers) in intended environment without training
usability_and_real_world.measurement_method: Recruit ≥100 untrained users representative of population; observe device use; assess critical steps, errors, and result interpretation
usability_and_real_world.success_criteria: ≥95% successfully perform all critical steps; ≥90% correctly interpret results; agreement with lab method ≥90% (PPA/NPA)
usability_and_real_world.source: FDA Self-Test IVD Guidance (2020), FDA Home-Use IVD Guidance
usability_and_real_world.clinical_significance: Demonstrates device is safe and effective when used by untrained laypersons in home environment
usability_and_real_world.typical_analysis: Proportion completing each critical step correctly; proportion with correct result interpretation; agreement (PPA/NPA) to lab comparator; stratify by demographics (age, education, health literacy)
usability_and_real_world.regulatory_notes: Required for all home-use and OTC IVDs; must include diverse population (age, education, health literacy, tech savvy); observe in simulated home environment; assess labeling comprehension

usability_and_real_world.name: Healthcare Provider Study (Point-of-Care)
usability_and_real_world.definition: Evaluation of device use by intended HCP users (nurses, MAs, pharmacists) in intended care setting
usability_and_real_world.measurement_method: Recruit ≥10-30 HCPs at ≥3 sites; provide IFU-only training; observe use on patient specimens or simulated specimens
usability_and_real_world.success_criteria: ≥95% successful results; agreement with lab comparator ≥95%; no critical use errors
usability_and_real_world.source: CLSI POCT07 (Point-of-Care Connectivity), FDA CLIA Waiver Guidance
usability_and_real_world.clinical_significance: Demonstrates device is suitable for use at point-of-care by non-laboratory personnel with minimal training
usability_and_real_world.typical_analysis: Task analysis with proportion completing critical steps correctly; agreement (PPA/NPA/OPA) to central lab; invalid rate <5%; turnaround time
usability_and_real_world.regulatory_notes: Required for CLIA-waived devices; must demonstrate simple operation with minimal training; assess error handling and QC compliance

usability_and_real_world.name: Specimen Type Comparison
usability_and_real_world.definition: Agreement between new specimen type (e.g., fingerstick whole blood) and standard specimen type (venipuncture plasma)
usability_and_real_world.measurement_method: Collect paired specimens from ≥100 patients; test both on device; calculate PPA/NPA/OPA or correlation
usability_and_real_world.success_criteria: PPA and NPA ≥90-95%; correlation R² ≥0.90 for quantitative tests
usability_and_real_world.source: CLSI H04 (Procedures for Collection of Capillary Blood), device-specific FDA guidance
usability_and_real_world.clinical_significance: Allows convenient specimen collection (fingerstick, oral fluid) for patient-facing tests
usability_and_real_world.typical_analysis: For qualitative: 2×2 table with PPA/NPA. For quantitative: Deming regression, Bland-Altman plot; assess bias and 95% limits of agreement
usability_and_real_world.regulatory_notes: FDA requires separate validation for each specimen type claimed; document collection procedure in IFU; assess impact of hematocrit for whole blood

usability_and_real_world.name: Invalid/Error Rate (Real-World)
usability_and_real_world.definition: Proportion of tests producing invalid result, error message, or no result in hands of intended users
usability_and_real_world.measurement_method: Track all attempted tests in usability or clinical study; categorize outcomes: valid result, invalid result, error code, user error
usability_and_real_world.success_criteria: Invalid rate <5% for professional use, <10% for home use
usability_and_real_world.source: Device-specific data from usability and clinical studies
usability_and_real_world.clinical_significance: High invalid rate wastes specimens, delays diagnosis, and erodes user confidence
usability_and_real_world.typical_analysis: Proportion invalid with 95% CI; categorize reasons (insufficient sample, QC failure, user error); assess if re-testing successful
usability_and_real_world.regulatory_notes: Report in clinical study; assess if invalid rate differs by user type, specimen type, or site; document troubleshooting procedures in IFU

notes.clsi_standards: CLSI (Clinical and Laboratory Standards Institute) publishes guidelines for IVD validation (EP series for analytical, C series for clinical chemistry, M series for microbiology)
notes.clia_requirements: Clinical Laboratory Improvement Amendments (CLIA) PT criteria define acceptable performance for lab certification; often used as regulatory benchmark
notes.reference_standards: Gold standard may be culture (microbiology), PCR (molecular), clinical diagnosis (symptoms + imaging), or expert adjudication
notes.sample_size: Analytical studies: 20-100 specimens per level. Clinical studies: ≥100-200 positive and ≥100-300 negative specimens for sensitivity/specificity claims; larger for rare diseases
notes.statistical_analysis: Use exact methods for proportions (Clopper-Pearson CI for sensitivity/specificity); Deming regression for method comparison (not OLS); stratify by relevant subgroups
notes.regulatory_pathways: Class I/II: 510(k) with predicate comparison; Class III or novel: PMA with clinical validation; CLIA waiver requires usability study demonstrating simple operation
notes.traceability: ISO 17511 and ISO 18113 series describe traceability and calibration requirements; document chain from device to primary reference material/method
